TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit RouteParameter extends System.Web.UI.WebControls.Parameter

Docs.summary: Binds the value of a URL segment to a parameter object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If you implement ASP.NET routing in a Web site, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter> object to bind the value of a segment of the requested URL to a database query or command. You can declare <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter> objects in markup for data source controls or the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.QueryExtender> control.
A Visual Studio Web site project with source code is available to accompany this topic: [Download](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=168640).
## Examples The examples in this section show how to use <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter> objects in markup to pass URL parameter values to a query that is specified for a data source control.
The following example shows code in the Global.asax page that defines a route that is named `ProductRoute`. The route defines a URL parameter that is named `productname`. The route also defines an optional catchall parameter that is named `culture`, which can be used to specify the language in which the product description is displayed. The Product.aspx page handles requests for this route.
The following example shows the Product.aspx page. The page contains a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.SqlDataSource> control that has a query that requires two parameters, one for the name of the product and one for the language of the product description. <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter> objects are used to supply the values for the query parameters. The value of the route URL parameter `productname` is passed to the query parameter `@productname`. The value of the route URL parameter `culture` is passed to the query parameter `@culture`. If a route URL does not include the URL parameter `culture`, a default value of "en" is used.
The following example shows a page that is named ProductLinks.aspx, which contains hyperlinks that link to the Product.aspx page by using route URLs. These hyperlinks use `RouteUrl` expressions to create route URLs. The first link does not include a `culture` route parameter. Therefore, the default value of "en" that is defined in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter> object for `@culture` query parameter will be used in the query. The second link provides a `culture` value of "fr", which causes the description to be displayed in French. For more information about how to use `RouteUrl` expressions, see [How to: Construct URLs from Routes](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/1ffd4085-71f6-4822-be8f-f682ca638650).
When you click the first hyperlink, you see the Product.aspx page with the following values in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control:
|ProductID|Name|Description| |---------------|----------|-----------------| |`994`|`LL Bottom Bracket`|`Chromoly steel.`|
When you click the second hyperlink, you see the following values in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control:
|ProductID|Name|Description| |---------------|----------|-----------------| |`994`|`LL Bottom Bracket`|`Acier chromÃ©.`|
To run this example, add the two .aspx pages and the code in the Global.asax file to an ASP.NET Web site or Web application that defines a connection string named `AdventureWorksLTConnectionString` for the AdventureWorksLT database. For information about how to set up a connection to the AdventureWorksLT database, see [How to: Set Up an AdventureWorksLT Sample Database for ASP.NET Development](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/2baad633-9d63-49cc-a6b2-917cafd35356).
For more information about ASP.NET routing, see [ASP.NET Routing](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/892441af-8f1d-483e-ab5f-b82c23576f5a).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You use this constructor method to initialize a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter> object and set default values. The properties are initialized to the following values:
- <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter.RouteKey%2A> is set to an empty string ("").
- <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Parameter.Name%2A> is set to an empty string.
- <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Parameter.Type%2A> is set to <xref:System.TypeCode.Empty>.
- <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Parameter.Direction%2A> is set to <xref:System.Data.ParameterDirection.Input>.
- <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Parameter.DefaultValue%2A> is set to `null`.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter original) cil managed

Docs.param: An object from which the current instance is initialized.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by using the values of the specified instance.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This constructor is used to clone a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter> instance.

Docs.param: The current instance of the request.
The control that the parameter is bound to.
Docs.summary: Evaluates the request URL and returns the value of the parameter.
Docs.returns: The current value of the parameter.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of the route segment from which to retrieve the value for the route parameter.
Docs.value: The name of the route segment that contains the value for the parameter.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When you define a route pattern, you can include segments that serve as placeholders for the actual values in the Web request URL. You define placeholders by enclosing them in braces ( `{` and `}` ). For example, a route pattern in the format `blog/{action}/{entry}` contains placeholders named `action` and `entry`. To retrieve the value of a placeholder, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter.RouteKey%2A> property to the name of the placeholder and call the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter.Evaluate%2A> method.
